The role of different state ZnO over non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel catalysts for isobutanol synthesis from syngas Shaopeng Tian a b Li Tan c Yingquan Wu a Yongli Kou a Hongjuan Xie a Noritatsu Tsubaki c Yisheng Tan a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan, Shanxi 030001, China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 China b Department of Foundation, Xijing University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710000, China Department of Foundation, Xijing University Xi’an Shaanxi 710000 China c Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, University of Toyama, Gofuku 3190, Toyama 930-8555, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, University of Toyama Gofuku 3190 Toyama 930-8555 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Catalysts with small zinc oxide particle size as well as good synergic effect between zinc oxide phase and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase plays an essential role in the process of isobutanol synthesis. A series of Zn–Cr based catalysts were prepared using combustion method (Comb-ZC), impregnation method (Impr-ZC), coprecipitation method (Copr-ZC) and fractional precipitation method (Frac-ZC). The catalysts were then examined for their ability to selectively convert syngas into higher alcohol with a special alcohol distribution (high selectivity for isobutanol). CO conversion of ca. 25%, alcohol selectivity of ca. 49% and selectivity of ca. 26% for isobutanol was achieved over the Frac-ZC catalyst. The better performance of Frac-ZC catalyst could be explained by smaller zinc oxide particle size, the higher proportion of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and the good synergic effects between zinc oxide phase and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase. The better reducibility as well as appropriate CO-absorption property of Frac-ZC catalyst also plays an essential role in the process of isobutanol synthesis. The study also shows the excess zinc oxide could aggravate the cation disorder distribution in non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure that provide more defects and oxygen vacancies for boosting isobutanol formation. Keywords Synthesis gas Zinc oxide Non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel Synergic effects Isobutanol 1 Introduction The requirements for petroleum-free sources of value-added chemicals will continue to increase in the future with increasing consumption of petroleum, demand for additives to increase the octane rating of gasoline, and concern about the environment [1–5]. Gasification of biomass or coal to syngas (mixture of H2 and CO) and its subsequent conversion to hydrocarbons via the Fischer–Tropsch reaction has been identified as a promising process for the production of “green”, high quality transportation fuels [6]. Besides hydrocarbons, the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas has also drawn considerable interest due to their potential application as a good gasoline additive or alternative motor fuel for improving the exhaust emission [7–9]. Among the higher alcohols, isobutanol is an important clean synthetic fuels and chemical intermediate [10–15]. Isobutanol is considered to be an effective and clean fuel for automobiles with a high octane rating. The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) approved isobutanol as a gasoline additive in 2010 [12]. Isobutanol is also widely studied for producing various chemicals, such as plasticizers and pharmaceuticals, etc. Until now, isobutanol is a petroleum-derived product; it is mainly produced through propylene carbonylation with high cost. The rapid increase in the consumption of isobutanol as well as the petroleum crisis means that a low-cost and petroleum-free method of manufacturing isobutanol is required. A promising non-noble metal family of catalysts, Zn–Cr based catalysts modified with alkali metal promoter, has been widely studied for isobutanol formation because of its longer time for remaining high activity, less severe coke deposition, and ability to form higher alcohols with high selectivity of isobutanol (alcohol distribution do not obey the A-S-F law) [10,16–19]. Oxides based on Zn and Cr have been studied extensively since the 1980s, and thorough reviews of the work that has been performed on these oxides have been published [1,13,20,21]. From the previous studies, the mechanism of CO hydrogenation is a complex reactions including water gas shift reaction, the formation of higher alcohol and alkane reaction, etc. In general, the zinc oxide phase is regarded as the active phase responsible for the formation of methanol while the non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel is identified as the active sites for the chain growth to form C2+ alcohol and isobutanol. Hence, it is crucial to obtain a well-designed catalyst with good synergic effects between the active sites of methanol and chain growth, otherwise the side reactions (water gas shift reaction, the formation of alkane reaction) will be severe. Members of our group have also studied the pathways and active sites involved in the formation of isobutanol from synthesis gas. We [12,22] found that isobutanol is formed through the addition of a C1 (formyl) intermediate to the α-carbon of methanol to produce alcohols with two or more carbon atoms (C2+ alcohol) and then the aldol condensation between methanol and these C2+ alcohols. We [11,14] also suggested that the cation disorder distribution in Zn–Cr spinel structure (non-stoichiometric spinel) affects tremendously the formation of isobutanol (cation disorder distribution means that the degree of Zn migrated to octahedral from tetrahedral position). The role of alkali metal over Zn–Cr catalyst was also studied deeply in our previous studies [23]. Both the populations and the stabilities of the oxygen species over the catalysts surface were found to be enhanced by the presence of alkali metal which would then facilitate the formation of alcohols. The nanoparticles ZnCr2O4 have been synthesized by various methods including mechanical activation [24], high-temperature solid-state reaction [25], micro-emulsion method [26], solution method [27], sol–gel method [28], combustion method [29] and spray pyrolysis [30], etc. The microstructure and properties of Zn–Cr spinels such as morphology, particle sizes, acid-base property and lattice constant are markedly influenced by their synthesized methods. These synthesized methods can be classified into two generic groups: solid state reaction and wet chemical methods. The disadvantage of solid state reaction is, in addition to the high synthesis temperature, the poor chemical homogeneity of the material obtained, will negatively influence the product properties. Wet chemical methods should, in principle, allow synthesis at lower temperatures and provide a more uniform cation distribution than solid state chemical reaction and better microstructural control. It is worth noting that all of our catalysts were prepared by a typical coprecipitation and postcalcined method in our previous studies. The coprecipitation method could provide catalysts with the most uniform chemical and physical properties of the preparation methods addresses and the particle size of catalysts could be easily controlled, but we have not investigate whether the coprecipitation method is the most appropriate method to prepare Zn–Cr catalysts for the formation of isobutanol for now. These ZnCr2O4 spinel powders synthesized by various methods also have been characterized by multiple techniques to establish structure–property relationship in many previous studies [24,31,32]. The structure of spinel oxide is responsible for a variety of interesting chemical and physical properties. However, only a few studies of “the structure–property–activity relationship” was reported. In our previous study [11,14], we have studied the role of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel for the formation of isobutanol from syngas. However, because our previous study focused on the structure of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel, we intentionally ignored the effect of excess zinc oxide on the Zn–Cr based catalysts to avoid the disturbance of excess zinc oxide phase and simplify the research system. The elemental ratio of Zn/Cr was limited to a certain range: less than 0.8 [11]. To be specific, if the elemental ratio of Zn/Cr is less than 0.8, the Zn–Cr oxides will form a spinel structure with cubic (f c c) cells, while if the elemental ratio of Zn/Cr is more than 0.8, some parts of Zn cations will form zinc oxide phase with wurtzite crystal structure that will disturb our experience and make the analysis of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure become much more difficult. In a word, the elemental ratio of Zn/Cr being 0.8 is the boundary point of whether the catalysts contain excess zinc oxide phase. The optimal elemental ratio of Zn/Cr for formation of isobutanol from syngas, however, is 1.2 which has been recognized in our previous experiments. As we mentioned above, once the elemental ratio of Zn/Cr of catalysts reaches to 1.2, besides the non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure, the excess Zn species will form zinc oxide phase. This makes us thinking: “what is the role of the excess zinc oxide for the formation of isobutanol from syngas and if these excess Zn species was introduced by some other way (not simple coprecipitation method but impregnation method or fractional precipitation method) the catalytic performance will be different or not?” In this paper, we prepared a series of Zn–Cr based catalysts by different methods including combustion method, impregnation method, coprecipitation method and fractional precipitation method and investigated their performances for the formation of isobutanol. These catalysts were then characterized by multiple techniques to explore the cause that the different catalytic performance over different catalysts and the role of different state zinc oxide for isobutanol formation in depth. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Combustion method Chromium nitrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O), zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), and citric acids (H3C6H5O7) were mixed in the appropriate molar ratios in a minimum volume of distilled water. The potassium promoter also was added into the initial materials as species of KNO3. The initial citric acids/nitrate molar ratio was limited to 1 and the Zn/Cr molar ratio was controlled to 1.2. The mixed solutions were heated for a few minutes at 80°C and the resulting viscous gel was introduced in an open muffle furnace, preheated at 300°C, in a ventilated cupboard. The gel started boiling with frothing and foaming, and in a couple of minutes ignited spontaneously with rapid evolution of a large quantity of gases, yielding a foamy, voluminous powder. The powder obtained after combustion contains also small amounts of carbonaceous residues, because the autoignition lasts only for a few seconds. In order to burn-off carbon residues and form the corresponding Zn–Cr spinel or spinel-like oxides, the powders were further heated at 400°C for 6h. Catalysts could be labeled as “Comb-ZC” for Zn–Cr catalysts prepared by combustion method. 2.1.2 Coprecipitation method The process of prepared catalyst was described in detail in our previous study [11,23]. The Zn/Cr molar ratio was limited to 1.2. catalysts could be labeled as “Copr-ZC” for Zn–Cr catalysts prepared by coprecipitation method. 2.1.3 Impregnation method Zn–Cr catalyst with Zn/Cr molar ratio being 0.8 was first prepared by a coprecipitation method which we have mentioned above. The catalyst was then impregnated with appropriate amounts of zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) by the incipient wetness method to make the molar ratio of Zn/Cr being 1.2 which is optimal elemental ratio of Zn/Cr for formation of isobutanol. Catalysts could be labeled as “Impr-ZC” for Zn–Cr catalysts prepared by impregnation method. 2.1.4 Fractional precipitation method Appropriate amounts (the Zn/Cr molar ratio is 0.8) of starting materials were prepared and pumped together by coprecipitation method as described above [11,23]. The excess zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) was introduced in the dark green suspension by coprecipitation method after it was aged for 1h. Catalysts could be labeled as “Frac-ZC” for Zn–Cr catalysts prepared by fractional precipitation method. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The instrumental techniques and test conditions of catalysts characterization was described in detail in our previous study [11,23] including high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS), Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR spectra), X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD). The Zn and Cr K-edge XAFS spectra of all samples were measured in the transmission mode at the beamline BL14Wl of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). Also, the test conditions of catalysts and the analysis software of the experimental data was described in detail in our previous study [14]. The linear combination fit of Zn K-edge spectra was performed using ATHENA code of Ravel. The XANES spectra of zinc oxide and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel are used as standards. The variable standards weights were constraint to be between 0 and 1. We also restrain that the weights sum to 1. R-factor, which is used to evaluate the reliability of fitting results, is defined as: R = sum ( data-fit ) 2 sum ( data ) 2 In our fitting process, R-factor ranged from 0.0001 to 0.001 which confirmed the goodness of refinement. 2.3 Activity measurements Each of these catalysts was tested for catalytic activity of isobutanol synthesis in a fixed bed. The description of experimental conditions and products analyses were sentenced in our previous article [11,14,23]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and microstructure of catalysts Representative transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of Zn–Cr nanocrystals prepared by different methods are shown in Fig. 1 . In our previous experiments, we have found that the catalysts with non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure all have particles of around 6nm in diameter while the catalysts with zinc oxide phase structure have particles of larger than 20nm in diameter. The microstructures of the catalysts, determined by high resolution TEM, confirm further this conclusion (shown in Fig. 1.2 and Fig. S1). The TEM and HRTEM images of catalysts prepared by combustion method (Comb-Cat) are shown in Fig. 1-a and Fig. S1-1. The catalysts with larger particle size, in a blue oval circle in Fig. 1-a, had a wurtzite crystal structure of zinc oxide phase, while the catalysts with smaller particle size, in a purple oval circle in Fig. 1-a, had a non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure. It can be found easily that the Comb-Cat catalyst has a typical characteristic of “two-phase separation”. Almost all of catalyst particles of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase separate from catalyst particles of zinc oxide phase. The synergic effects between non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and zinc oxide phase, which maybe one of the key factors for isobutanol formation in Zn–Cr based catalyst, should be extremely small over Comb-ZC catalyst from the results of Fig. 1-a. The TEM and HRTEM images of catalysts prepared by impregnation method (Impr-ZC) are shown in Fig. 1-b and Fig. S1-2. It can be found that the particle size of zinc oxide is expressly large (larger than 50nm), while the particle size of Zn–Cr spinel remain the same as catalysts prepared by other methods (around 6nm). The large particle size of zinc oxide will generally partly cover the sites responsible for the formation of isobutanol and negatively affect the catalyst performance. The TEM and HRTEM images of catalysts prepared by coprecipitation method (Copr-ZC) and fractional precipitation method (Frac-ZC) are shown in Fig. 1-c (Fig. S1-3) and Fig. 1-d (Fig. 1B). The particle size of zinc oxide phase of Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts were similar and much smaller than that of Comb-Cat and Impr-ZC catalysts. The smaller particle size of catalysts, in principle, should provide more active sites responsible for the formation of isobutanol and greatly improve their catalytic performance. A close look of the high resolution TEM (HRTEM) images in Fig. 1B and Fig. S1-1 to Fig. S1-3, numerous of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase (smaller particle size) was around the zinc oxide phase (bigger particle size) over Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts, while the situation was not found over Comb-ZC and Impr-ZC catalysts. It suggested that the synergic effects between non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and zinc oxide phase over Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts were much better than that over Comb-ZC and Impr-ZC catalysts. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts using powder X-ray diffractometry The powder X-ray diffractometry (XRD) patterns of Zn–Cr nanocrystals prepared by different methods are shown in Fig. 2 . All the catalysts prepared by different methods had similar X-ray diffraction patterns, which suggested that all the crystalline structure of catalysts had no obvious change and there were no other special phases appeared. No diffraction peaks for potassium species were found in any of the XRD patterns. No K2O (JCPDS card 47-1701) or K2CO3 (JCPDS card 49-1093) peaks were found, possibly because the K2O phases over the catalysts surfaces were highly divided. The main reflections were consistent with crystalline zinc oxide and non-stoichiometric spinel (Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O) [30,33]. As suggested by previous researchers, the non-stoichiometric spinel is considerably crucial for isobutanol formation on the Zn–Cr based catalysts [34–36]. The zinc oxide diffraction intensity of Impr-Cat catalyst is much stronger than catalysts prepared by other methods, illustrating that larger particle size and better crystallinity of zinc oxide have been established by impregnation method. That is consistent with TEM images analysis. It is worth noting that the zinc oxide diffraction intensity of Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC is much weaker than the others, suggesting smaller particle size of zinc oxide has been highly divided on the catalysts surface, or (and) some excess zinc oxide may be inside the spinel structure to form more non-stoichiometric spinel phase which will be discussed in detail in XAFS spectra part. 3.3 Texture parameters of catalysts The texture parameters for the catalysts prepared by different methods are shown in Table 1 . The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas (S BET) of the catalysts increased linearly from 54.0m2 g−1 to 89.6m2 g−1 in sequence of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts, and The Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts had a similar BET surface areas (88.3 and 89.6m2 g−1). The variation trend of S BET could be explained by the various particle sizes of zinc oxide which had been confirmed by TEM images and XRD patterns. The pore volumes and radii of catalysts are also influenced by the particle size of zinc oxide. Larger pore radii and pore volumes prefer bigger molecule (isobutanol) diffusing from the active sites inside the pore, which maybe a non-ignorable factor for better performance for the formation of isobutanol. 3.4 XANES analysis of the catalysts The metal ions distribution in an ideal normal/inverse Zn–Cr spinel structure have been described in our previous studies [11,14,23]. However, most spinel compounds deviate from the ideal normal/inverse spinel distributions and the metal ions distribution in Zn–Cr spinel structure is affected by various factors, such as the calcination temperature, electronic states, ion sizes, and particle sizes, etc. [37]. The physical and chemical properties of a material with a spinel structure can be tailored by controlling the cations that occupy the tetrahedral and octahedral coordination sites. It was therefore crucial for us to investigate the cation distributions in the Zn–Cr spinel structures in our catalysts. Normalized Zn K-edge XANES spectra of catalysts prepared by different methods are shown in Fig. 3 . There were three resolved peaks and a significant shoulder at the white line region, which reflected the electronic transition from zinc 1s core level to unoccupied states of p type [38]. We have confirmed in our previous study [14] that the striking features appeared around 9668eV and 9680eV at Zn-K edge (named feature A and feature B for simple) result from cation exchange in Zn–Cr spinel structure. Feature A increases while feature B decreases in amplitude in sequence as of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC, suggesting that the degree of cation disorder distribution increases in the same sequence as of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts. In a similar report for the spinel structure of ZnFe2O4, Stewart et al. [38] have shown almost the same changing trend of feature A and feature B for the Zn K-edge XANES spectrum when the degree of cation disorder distribution increases. Chen et al. [39] also confirmed the same conclusion through performing Zn K-edge XANES simulations for the normal ZnCr2O4 structure and for isolated Zn atom substituting Cr at octahedral sites. Hence, a conclusion could be taken cautiously that the change trend of feature A and feature B shows an important local structural change in Zn–Cr spinel which results from considerable zinc cations transference from tetrahedral to octahedral sites. Fig. 4 shows the normalized Cr K-edge XANES spectra of catalysts prepared by different methods. The pre-edge peak (see inset in Fig. 4, upper left corner) increased while the absorption-edge was shifted to higher energy (see inset in Fig. 4, bottom right corner) in sequence as of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts. The mechanisms of pre-edge peak have been previously described in detail [14]. In a word, the pre-edge peak is allowed in a tetrahedral symmetry but forbidden in the octahedral one. Thus, the increase of the pre-edge peak intensity reflects the increase of the occupation number of Cr atom in tetrahedral sites (the degree of cation disorder distribution) shown as follows: Comb-ZC<Impr-ZC<Copr-ZC<Frac-ZC catalysts. In addition, absorption-edge of the Cr K-edge XANES spectra (inset in Fig. 4, bottom right side) moving to higher energy also points out the increase of the degree of cation disorder distribution. All data are well consistent with the analysis results of the Zn K-edge. 3.5 EXAFS analysis The corresponding Fourier transforms of Zn K-edges are compared in Fig. 5 . The crystal local structure of Zn–Cr spinel has been described in our previous studies [14]. In theory, the first and second shell distance from the central Zn atom is 1.97 and 3.45Å while the first and second shell distance from central Cr atom is 1.99 and 2.94Å differently. In fact, as shown in Fig. 5, the first and second peak for EXAFS of Zn K-edge appears at around 1.60 and 3.01Å instead of 1.97 and 3.45Å because of the instrumental error. The second peak for EXAFS of Cr K-edge, as shown in Fig. S2-3, appears at around 2.60Å (not at 2.94Å) also result from the same reason [39]. We may point out that, except for the two normal intensive peaks centered on around 1.60 and 3.01Å, an additional relatively weaker peak appears at about 2.60Å, which clearly results from the cation disorder distribution. Stewart et al. [38] have observed similar results in the Zn K-edge of ZnFe2O4. For our samples, depending on the corresponding atomic distance mentioned above, when Zn atoms substitute to octahedral sites, a new shell would appear at about 2.60Å, resulting in a new peak. Not surprisingly, the location of this additional peak is definitely as same as the second coordination distance of Cr (seen in Fig. S2-3). It clearly confirms that some part of Zn cations have entered into the octahedral sites which signifies the cation disorder distribution appears. The new peak around 2.6Å increases in amplitude while the peak around 3.01Å decreases in a sequence of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC, demonstrating the trend of more serious cation disorder distribution. All analysis is consistent with XANES analysis. From the analysis of XANES and EXAFS, one conclusion could be cautiously stated that the excess zinc oxide could aggravate the cation disorder distribution in non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure no matter how zinc oxide was introduced to the catalyst. In principle, smaller particle size of zinc oxide causes higher degree of cation disorder distribution which is shown as following: Comb-ZC<Impr-ZC<Copr-ZC<Frac-ZC catalysts. 3.6 Linear combination fitting analysis Fig. 6 shows the curves of linear combination XANES fits (LC-XANES fits) of the catalysts prepared by different methods. Linear combination fitting analysis might be used to deduce the species and quantities of standards in a heterogeneous sample, by fitting each standards spectrum as a linear combination of the end members [40]. We have confirmed that our catalysts contain zinc oxide phase and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase in XRD patterns in Fig. 2. Hence, the XANES spectra of zinc oxide and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel were used as standards to fitting our XANES spectra of catalysts. The XANES spectra of model compounds and catalysts are showed in Fig. S3. The LCF results of the catalysts prepared by different methods are presented in Fig. 6 and Table 2 . The percentage of zinc oxide phase of our catalysts decreased from 20.4% to 13.2% while the non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase increased from 79.6% to 86.8% in the order of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC, and Frac-ZC catalysts. From the XANES and EXAFS analysis above, we have discovered that the degree of cation disorder distribution became higher in the same sequence. In all probability, the decreased zinc oxide has migrated into the Zn–Cr spinel structure to form more non-stoichiometric spinel phase and make the cation disorder distribution more serious. Numerous scholars have also found, during preparing Zn–Cr catalysts, when the elemental ratio of Zn/Cr is bigger than Zn–Cr spinel in theory, the excess Zn ions may have been present within the spinel structure to form non-stoichiometric spinel structure. Giamello [34–36] and coworkers prepared Zn–Cr oxides with Zn/Cr molar ratios of 1 and only found one phase of non-stoichiometric spinel. They confirmed, from the results of characterizations, that the excess zinc oxide may migrate into the spinel structure to form non-stoichiometric spinel structure. Vaccari [34,41] reached the same conclusions. Previous studies processed by Marinković [24] and Calvin [42], as well as our group [11,14,23] has also shown that, despite the strong affinity of zinc cations for tetrahedral sites, attempts to synthesize Zn–Cr spinel by various routes may yield significant amounts of zinc in the octahedral sites to form non-stoichiometric spinel and make the cation distribution in Zn–Cr spinel more disordered. We may cautiously conclude, from LCF results as well as the XAFS analysis, that parts of extra zinc cations will be present within the spinel structures, causing the cations disorder distribution in non-stoichiometric spinel structures to be more serious. Because non-stoichiometric spinel in a more disordered fashion has more defects and oxygen vacancies that can activate reactants more easily, it is a more effective catalyst for the formation of isobutanol. Giamello [34–36] and coworkers held the point that the non-stoichiometry phase led the catalytic activity to generating alcohol. In previous research [11,14,23], we also found that the non-stoichiometric spinel is essential for the formation of isobutanol, and the more serious cation disorder distribution, the better catalytic performance. 3.7 XPS characterization of various catalysts The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . Features caused by the presence of Zn and Cr were all quite prominent. The spectra contained Zn2p peaks at around 1022.2eV and 1045.2eV and Cr3+ peaks at around 576.4eV and 586.0eV, showing that the Zn and Cr species in the near-surface regions of the catalysts were primarily present as zinc oxide or Zn–Cr spinel [43,44]. The spectrum of each catalyst also contained a Cr6+ peak at 578.1eV, indicating that each of catalysts had probably been over-oxidized [45]. In a previous study [46], Baltistoni found that all of the Zn2p and Cr2p binding energy values for the non-stoichiometric spinel compounds lie, within the experimental errors, slightly larger than those for ZnO and Cr2O3. The difference could be attributed to the different Madelung potential contribution in the spinels and in the oxide. In previous studies [14], we also found that the binding energy values of Zn and Cr ions in non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure moved to higher energy than normal Zn–Cr spinel. The Zn2p and Cr2p binding energy values increased in the order of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC, and Frac-ZC catalysts, most likely resulting from the formation of non-stoichiometric spinel with more defects and oxide vacancies. This is consistent with the results and analysis of XANES and EXAFS. 3.8 H2-TPR analysis of the catalysts The redox properties of different catalysts were evaluated by performing H2-TPR analyses of catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . Each catalyst had only one main hydrogen consumption peak in the temperature range from 300 to 400°C which could be attribute to the reduction of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel [10]. The hydrogen consumption values for the Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC samples were about 1.01mmol/g, 1.21mmol/g, 1.44mmol/g, and 1.61mmol/g, respectively. It has previously been found that Zn2+ and Cr3+ in Zn–Cr normal spinel are very difficult to reduce. However, each of catalysts was in a “metastable state” because of the presence of non-stoichiometric spinel with a considerable proportion of metal ions disordered distribution, the non-stoichiometric spinel owns more defects and oxygen vacancies and that would have allowed our catalysts to be reduced much more easily than normal Zn–Cr spinel. Our XPS analyses of the samples showed that the Zn and Cr valences were higher in our samples than in normal spinel, which also meant that our catalysts could be reduced much more easily than normal spinel. After H2 adsorption, chemical compound zinc oxide has become free state Zn2+; the active species in the studied reaction are free state Zn2+ located in octahedral site (disordered distribution) inside of the nonstoichiometric spinel structure. If the reducibility of non-stoichiometric spinel is higher, there will be more free state Zn2+ formed from chemical compound zinc oxide, as a result the catalyst activity will be better. 3.9 CO-TPD analysis of the catalysts The CO adsorption characterization of reduced catalysts is estimated by Temperature Programmed Desorption of CO analyses (CO-TPD) and the results are reported in Fig. 9 . Nearly similar changing trends of desorption peaks for CO was observed. All of these CO-TPD patterns had three peaks, namely, weak CO adsorption at 120.0°C (label as peak α) moderate CO adsorption at 280.5°C (label as peak γ) and strong CO adsorption at 380.0°C (label as peak γ). When the specific uptakes are compared, it is obvious that the moderate CO uptakes are increasing in a sequence of Comb-ZC, Impr-ZC, Copr-ZC and Frac-ZC catalysts. In general, in a heterogeneous catalytic reaction, there are three necessary steps for the reactants to become products, namely reactant adsorption on catalyst surface, surface reaction and products desorption from the surface of catalyst. Appropriate adsorption strength is essential for our reaction; weak adsorption cannot induce surface reaction and strong adsorption will cause the dissociation of CO and form by-products (mainly CH x species). On the basis of above observations, it seems that the prepared methods could regulate the CO adsorption strength, which may play an essential role in alcohol synthesis. That could be another non-ignorable factor for different performance when catalysts were prepared by different methods. 3.10 Catalytic activity measurements The catalytic activities of the samples for the synthesis of isobutanol and MeOH are shown in Table 3 . As a complement, the catalytic performance of the Frac-ZC catalysts with different Zn/Cr elemental ratio and under different Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) for the formation of isobutanol are shown in Tables S1 and S2. As reference, the catalytic performances of zinc oxide and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase are also shown in Table S3. In Table 3, only 17.4% of the CO was converted by the Comb-ZC catalyst, and the selectivity for isobutanol was poor (isobutanol contributed 13.6% of the alcohols produced), but the alcohol selectivity reached to maximum to 50.9%. The CO conversion of Impr-ZC catalyst increased a little to 19.7% and the selectivity for isobutanol was improved to 18.0%. However, the alcohol selectivity lowered to minimum to 38.6%. The Copr-ZC catalyst increased the CO conversion to 21.9% and improved the isobutanol selectivity to 19.4%. The catalyst prepared by fraction precipitation (Frac-ZC catalyst) presented an excellent performance for the formation of isobutanol from syngas. The CO conversion was enhanced to 25.2%; the isobutanol selectivity was greatly improved to 26.0%; and the total alcohol rate also reached the maximum. Almost all of the indexes about the catalytic performance is greater than that attained by Tao Jiang [47] and Noritatsu [10] (one of our partners) using a K/ZnO/Cr2O3 catalyst. It is also much better than the results achieved in our previous studies [11,14,23]. The poor performance of Comb-ZC catalyst for isobutanol formation may be result from the “two-phase separation” which causes poor synergic effects between non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and Zinc oxide phase. The best alcohol selectivity (50.9%) of Comb-ZC catalyst should explained by the poor activity of zinc oxide phase (shown in Table S3) and “two-phase separation”. In general, higher GHSV leads higher total alcohol selectivity (seen in Table S1). In other dimension, the Comb-ZC catalyst contains two almost separate phase; one of them (the zinc oxide phase) owns very poor catalytic activity, that would increase the GHSV on another more active phase (the non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase) and causes higher alcohol selectivity. The Impr-ZC catalyst owns the worst alcohol selectivity and total alcohol rate which could due to the extremely largest particle size (larger than 50nm) of zinc oxide. The largest particle size of zinc oxide over the surface of catalyst should cover some active sites for isobutanol formation and suppress the catalytic performance. The Copr-ZC catalyst shows a much better catalytic performance than the results obtained by Comb-ZC and Impr-ZC catalysts because of the smaller particle size of zinc oxide and the better synergic effects between non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and zinc oxide phase. The Frac-ZC catalyst has the best catalytic performance for isobutanol formation from syngas. Over the Frac-ZC catalyst, CO conversion reaches to the best of 25.2%, alcohol selectivity reaches to 48.9%, total alcohol production rate reaches to the highest value of 0.098gml−1 h−1, and the isobutanol selectivity is enhanced to maximum to 26.0%. Besides the smaller particle size of zinc oxide and the better synergic effects between non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and zinc oxide phase, the Frac-ZC catalyst also owns the maximum of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase. The better reducibility and property of moderate CO-adsorption also are crucial for the better catalytic performance. From the results and discussions of the characterizations about catalysts, one conclusion may be cautiously obtained, that the excess zinc oxide over Zn–Cr based catalysts could affect a number of physical and chemical properties of catalysts and further make different influences for their catalytic performance for the formation of isobutanol from syngas. In general, the zinc oxide phase is regarded as the active phase responsible for the formation of methanol [16,44] and the non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel is identified as the active sites for the formation of isobutanol [13,34–36]. The mechanism of isobutanol formation is a complex consecutive reactions; methanol is the initial product in the first step reaction and also the reactant for the next step reaction to produce C2+ alcohol and isobutanol. It is crucial to obtain a well-designed catalyst with good synergic effects between the active sites of methanol and isobutanol formation. Smaller particle size of zinc oxide would dramatically promote the formation of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel and enhance the synergic effects between them. The zinc oxide also aggravates the cation disorder distribution in non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure that causes much defects and oxygen vacancies. These defects and oxygen vacancies could lower markedly the activation energy of the reactions are required and, of course, benefit the catalytic performance a lot. In another dimension, it seems that a proper content of zinc oxide phase presented on Zn–Cr catalysts could improve the catalytic performance until the content of zinc oxide phase reaches to the optimal value. It must be stressed here that, methanol, the initial product for isobutanol formation, could be generated easily over our catalysts, while the chain growth step, to produce C2+ alcohol and isobutanol from methanol, is more difficult and of course more essential for our reaction. Therefore, the non-stoichiometric spinel is more crucial than zinc oxide phase for the formation of isobutanol over Zn–Cr based catalysts. That is one of the reasons why the higher percentage of non-stoichiometric spinel makes better catalytic performance in catalysts. The reducibility, texture parameters and appropriate CO-absorption property of catalysts are some other non-ignorable factors for the formation of isobutanol over Zn–Cr based catalysts from syngas. 4 Conclusions In this report, we prepared the Zn–Cr based catalysts using different methods including combustion, impregnation, coprecipitation and fractional precipitation methods and then investigated the catalytic activity and performance of catalysts for isobutanol synthesis from syngas. Among the tested catalysts, the catalysts prepared by fractional precipitation (Frac-ZC) displayed the highest CO conversion of ca. 25%, the largest total alcohol production rate of 0.098gml−1 h−1 and the highest isobutanol selectivity of ca. 26%. The excess zinc oxide over Zn–Cr based catalysts plays an essential role for the formation of isobutanol from syngas. A proper content of zinc oxide phase presented on Zn–Cr catalysts could greatly improve their catalytic performance. Smaller particle size of Zinc oxide would dramatically promote the formation of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel and enhance the synergic effects between them. The zinc oxide also aggravates the cation disorder distribution in non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel that causes much more defects and oxygen vacancies. These defects and oxygen vacancies could lower markedly the activation energy of the reactions are required and benefit the catalytic performance a lot. The reducibility, texture parameters and appropriate CO-absorption property of catalysts are some other non-ignorable factors for the formation of isobutanol over Zn–Cr based catalysts from syngas. coredata.dc:description: A series of Zn–Cr based catalysts were prepared using combustion method (Comb-ZC), impregnation method (Impr-ZC), coprecipitation method (Copr-ZC) and fractional precipitation method (Frac-ZC). The catalysts were then examined for their ability to selectively convert syngas into higher alcohol with a special alcohol distribution (high selectivity for isobutanol). CO conversion of ca. 25%, alcohol selectivity of ca. 49% and selectivity of ca. 26% for isobutanol was achieved over the Frac-ZC catalyst. The better performance of Frac-ZC catalyst could be explained by smaller zinc oxide particle size, the higher proportion of non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase and the good synergic effects between zinc oxide phase and non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel phase. The better reducibility as well as appropriate CO-absorption property of Frac-ZC catalyst also plays an essential role in the process of isobutanol synthesis. The study also shows the excess zinc oxide could aggravate the cation disorder distribution in non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel structure that provide more defects and oxygen vacancies for boosting isobutanol formation.
coredata.dc:title: The role of different state ZnO over non-stoichiometric Zn–Cr spinel catalysts for isobutanol synthesis from syngas
